Award.AwardTitle: Beyond Stability of Black Holes in General Relativity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project strives to answer fundamental questions about strong field dynamics in general relativity, including black hole processes and the formation and structure of spacetime singularities. These questions can be expressed in mathematics and the project will contribute to the venerable tradition of rigorous mathematics making fundamental statements about our physical world, a tradition which in the long run has proven central to advances in science and technology. The subject of black holes and spacetime singularities has inspired the popular imagination well beyond the confines of the scientific community, as was apparent in the public reception of the
detection of gravitational waves from binary black hole systems and, most recently, of the first stunning images of the immediate vicinity of a supermassive black hole. The PI and co-PI will also contribute to broader impacts via training of PhD students on problems related to the research in this project.

This project strives to advance beyond the study of stability problems in general relativity and answer fundamental questions about strong field dynamics of the theory, including non-linear aspects of gravitational scattering, the fine structure of gravitational radiation and the nature of spacetime singularities. The first major objective of this project, based on a long sequence of previous joint work of the proposers, is to finish up the mathematical proof of the non-linear stability of the Kerr black hole metric. The second major objective of this project concerns understanding the structure of spacetime singularities inside black holes, aiming to understand their general form, in particular, whether they eventually become strong and spacelike. A third and final major objective concerns the question of whether singularities exist in the vacuum which are not hidden in black holes. The project aims to answer this question in the affirmative, investigating also the stability of these singularities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As an outcome of this project, progress was made on understanding several fundamental questions in the theory of General Relativity connected to black holes and spacetime singularities. These questions reduce to purely mathematical problems concerning a complicated system of equations known as the Einstein equations, first written down in 1915 by Einstein. One outcome of this project was the completion of the first proof of the stability of non-rotating Schwarzschild black holes, without symmetry assumptions and in the context of the full nonlinear theory. It also developed the tools allowing for a future extension of the result to the rapidly rotating Kerr case, up to the so-called extremal limit. Deep inside black holes, but also at the Big Bang at the beginning of our universe, General Relativity predicts the existence of spacetime singularities. The generic geometric structure of these singularities, however, is poorly understood, in particular, whether the spacetime curvature necessarily blows up and whether observers falling into such singularity are necessarily torn apart. Another outcome of this project was a complete geometric description of the singularities that occur in a large class of spacetimes without any symmetry assumptions, in the case where matter is described by a scalar field. This may be viewed as a first step in a future complete description of generic singularities in general relativity, both for more realistic matter or for vacuum. A final outcome of the project was the development of a new gluing technique for pasting together two solutions of the Einstein equations to form a new one with prescribed properties. This has led to several applications by other groups, including the recent disproof of the so-called ``third law of black hole thermodynamics''. The main results of the proposal were published in highly selective peer reviewed mathematics journals and in addition in publicly available preprint servers. They were also disseminated in a large number of scientific colloquia, seminar talks, and named lecture series delivered by the investigators, at universities throughout the country and also abroad, in addition to major scientific conferences where the investigators participated. They were also disseminated in a variety of online events, particularly during the period of disruption due to the pandemic. Many of these presentations were recorded on video and are publicly available. In addition, the investigators themselves organised several workshops and summer schools where this research was disseminated, along with research of many other groups. Finally, some of the research was presented in a form accessible to the general public in public talks given by the investigators.
